string_table.name: pxabnsnfns10111010101
string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.

terms.term: compact clay and limestone soil found in the Chianti region of Tuscany
soil material transported by water.
the direction in which a slope faces.
a fine-grained particle with excellent water retention properties.
the long-term weather pattern of a given area.
soil material transported downslope by gravity.
a climate with a wide annual range of temperatures.
the difference between the day and night temperatures of a given climate; higher diurnal ranges are associated with wines of greater acidity.
a type of limestone rock.
a sites height above sea level.
soil material transported by water, particularly when associated with glacial movements.
a friable marl of layered limestone and sandstone.
soil transported by the movement of glaciers (slow-moving ice rivers).
a hard, mineral-rich rock that warms quickly and retails heat.
also known as degree days. A way to classify the growth potential of a climate by measuring daily mean temperatures during the growing season.
the distance north or south of the equator as measured by degrees and minutes.
an alkaline (which encourages high acidity) sedimentary soil that is made up of carbonates.
an ideal soil that is warm, crumbly, and a balanced mixture of sand, silt, and clay.
soil transported by wind.
a hard, blue/grey sandstone found in the Chianti region of Tuscany.
climate measured broadly as in an entire region.
the opposite of a continental climate in that it has a narrow range of annual temperatures.
a colder, limestone clay soil that delays ripening and helps enhance the acidity in a wine.
characterized by warm, dry summers and mild, wet winters.
smaller than a macroclimate, this usually refers to the climate of a given vineyard site.
the smallest measurement of a climate, usually a single vine or the canopy within the vines.
soils deposited by the retreat of glaciers.
the process in which sunlight is trapped by green chlorophyll pigments in the leaves and converted to glucose for a plants energy.
a type of rock formed by magma/lava that comes in a variety of colors and includes large crystals.
fragments of bedrock that are prized because they allow for good water drainage.
a sedimentary rock of sand-sized particles that have been formed by pressure.
a heat-retaining rock that splits cleanly, thus ideal for roots to penetrate and water to drain through.
a very fine deposit (with a particle size between clay and sand) with good water retention.
the degree of incline in a vineyard.
literally means soil, but generally refers to the natural elements of a vineyard site such as climate, soils and topography.
the specific climate events (frost, rain, temperature, etc.) for a given site. The weather of a vineyard has an important influence on the vintage characteristics for a wine.
